DOC.HEAD: Noriega Deputy Asks Marines for Return of Ranch
DOC.UNK: EDITOR'S NOTE: The following is a pool report filed by Steven Komarow of The Associated Press and Kathy Lewis of the Houston Post.
DOC.TEXT: A top deputy to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega telephoned U.S. marines who were occupying his ranch and asked for it back, soldiers said Saturday. Rigoberto Paredes, Noriega's political chief in the area west of Panama City and the reputed head of the local Noriega secret police, was told he could reclaim the ranch and a nearby mansion if he surrendered. He did not, and when the marines left the property on another mission, angry local residents sacked it. They ``looted the house and set it afire,'' said Cpl. Jeff Newsome of Norfolk, Va. Newsome said he took part in the initial attack when U.S. forces fired upon and destroyed a local headquarters for Noriega's police. The burned-out, two-story station was empty but adorned Saturday with a large makeshift banner declaring ``Endara Presidente.'' Guillermo Endara was sworn in as president of Panama when the U.S. operation commenced on Wednesday. The United States considers him the winner of the May election in Panama which Noriega declared void. Arraijan, along the Pan American Highway, was still largely isolated Saturday as the U.S. military continued its operations. The local citizens drank beer and watched as the soldiers took into custody Noriega loyalists who were surrendering. Shops, some of them which had been looted, were closed and citizens said they had no food or water. ``We have wanted change for 20 years,'' said Bernalldo Altamirri. ``We want everything finished. We want to pass a good Christmas and a good New Year's.'' ``If they do not catch Noriega, it is not finished,'' he said of the U.S. operation. Felipe Barrera said, ``President Bush said he is sending food. I don't see it.''
